title: Phrack Pro-Phile XXIX
historical_context: This article provides insights into the early hacker and phreaker culture, featuring Emmanuel Goldstein, a prominent figure in the community and editor of a notable phreak/hack newsletter.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This edition of Phrack Pro-Phile features an interview with Emmanuel Goldstein, exploring his background, experiences in hacking and phreaking, and his views on the evolution of the hacker community.
summary:
In this engaging installment of Phrack Pro-Phile, Taran King presents an in-depth interview with Emmanuel Goldstein, a significant figure in the hacking and phreaking community. Goldstein shares his journey from early phone experimentation to his involvement in the burgeoning world of computers. He reflects on the importance of social engineering and the thrill of exploration in both technology and life. Goldstein emphasizes that hacking is about asking questions and being persistent, a philosophy that has guided his experiences throughout the years.

Goldstein also discusses the evolution of bulletin board systems (BBS) and the need for privacy rights within these platforms. He recounts memorable encounters with notable figures in the hacking world and highlights the diverse backgrounds of those involved in the community. The article serves as a reminder of the shared spirit among hackers across generations, urging readers to embrace exploration and creativity while navigating the complexities of technology and society. Goldstein's insights resonate with both seasoned hackers and newcomers, making this article a valuable read for anyone interested in the history and culture of hacking.
